Tom's proposed solution to the problem of excessive copyright duration raises an awkward ethical question. If a musician wrote a song or cut a record in 1970, say, he might - quite reasonably - have thought that this would bring in a handy few shillings for him throughout his life AND do the same for his children. (He probably wouldn't have considered any further down the family tree.) He would have relied upon the law as it stood, which is EXACTLY what we demand of all citizens. It would therefore be grossly unfair to change the copyright duration *retrospectively*, so Tom's 50-yr. rule would only apply to works published after the date of the rule's enactment. Therefore, the rule-change would only start to bear fruit 50 years afterwards, and it would only apply to a small portion of "classic" songs (because I believe that, in fifty years time, we'll still consider the 60s and 70s to be the golden age of pop and rock). It would still be worth doing, mind, as it would pay off eventually, to some extent, but would the punters be satisfied with this outcome, or would they demand retrospective law-changes, regardless of jurists' objections?

Not that many people; certainly, not the individual creators who would love the chance to use the Star Wars IP for their own projects. Copyright length should depend on the reasonable investment needed to create the content and the term over which a return on that investment is reasonable. Consider patents, where the term of patent protection is allegedly matched to the time period that a sufficient return on that investment can be made without compromising the creative abilities of others to advance the art and build on prior inventions. It is a balancing act, but the principle is to allow those who invest a day and a small budget on a project a chance to earn proportionate to that art, to allow the one who invested years writing a novel a chance to receive the reward for his sacrifice, and those who spend large sums investing in a production and seeding the arts a chance to reap the reward for their commitment.  I consider it unreasonable to ever allow any art to be copyright protected following the death of the artist. Corporations holding copyrights should have shorter protection tenure than individual holders.  Finally, a lot of content that has copyright claim is a derived work, and that also needs to be addressed, because the effort needed to produce 100% original art is magnitudes harder than reworking, repackaging, re-recording, assembling, or parroting prior art.
